Award.AwardTitle: Floer homology and surfaces in 3- and 4-manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates a variety of questions in low-dimensional topology, the study of the global shapes of 3- and 4-dimensional spaces, which has a wide variety of applications ranging from astrophysics (the shape of the universe) to biochemistry (the knotting of DNA molecules) to theoretical physics. Much of the interesting topological information about a 3- or 4-dimensional space is captured in the types of surfaces that are embedded in that space, and this project aims to obtain restrictions on the types of such surfaces that can be found in various classes of spaces. The PI's primary tools come from Heegaard Floer homology, a package of invariants that has become one of the dominant areas of research in low-dimensional topology since its introduction in the early 2000s by Ozsváth and Szabó. These techniques bring together several different fields of mathematics, including representation theory, homological algebra, analysis, and mathematical physics, and the PI hopes to elucidate the connections between these different areas and expand the discourse among researchers in these fields.

The specific goals of the project are (1) to understand the relationship between the Heegaard Floer homology of a 3-manifold and topological properties such as the existence of incompressible surfaces, taut foliations, and left-orderings on the fundamental group; (2) to solve concrete topological problems regarding smoothly embedded surfaces in 4-manifolds, in part by using new computational techniques made possible by bordered Floer homology; and (3) to use the recently-developed spanning tree models for knot Floer homology and Khovanov homology to shed light on the long-conjectured relationship between the two theories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates a variety of questions in low-dimensional topology, the study of the global shapes of 3- and 4-dimensional spaces and of knots and surfaces contained within them. This subject lies at the crossroads of many disparate areas of mathematics, and it has deep connections with subjects ranging from cosmology (the shape of the universe) to biochemistry (the knotting of DNA molecules) to mathematical physics. Surprisingly, many problems in low dimensions are usually more difficult than their analogues in higher dimensions and require the use of invariants that go beyond traditional algebraic topology. The PI's particular area of expertise is in Heegaard Floer homology, a collection of invariants for 3- and 4-dimensional manifolds, which has been one of the most fruitful areas of research in low-dimensional topology since the early 2000s. These tools bring together several different fields of mathematics, including representation theory, differential geometry, and analysis.
During the grant period, the PI made significant breakthroughs on a variety of problems in this field, leading to four published or accepted papers and several more that are in preparation. These results include:
  • Knot concordance is the study of which knots in a 3-dimensional space can or cannot occur as the boundaries of embedded disks in a 4-dimensional space, a widely-studied subject motivated by the study of singularities of surfaces. In a paper in 2014, the PI solved a 40-year-old problem asking whether one can obstruct knots from bounding not only smoothly embedded disks but disks with certain types of singularities. In more recent ongoing work with Tye Lidman (North Carolina State University) and Jennifer Hom (Georgia Tech), the PI has developed many new tools for studying this extended version of knot concordance.
  • In a 2016 paper with Daniel Ruberman (Brandeis University), the PI used Heegaard Floer homology to provide new numerical invariants for a certain class of 4-dimensional manifolds. (Previous efforts had managed to define these invariants only under certain restrictive hypotheses, which are not necessary for the PI's approach.) In principle, these invariants can be used to detect so-called exotic smooth structures on certain 4-manifolds, which has been a driving goal of 4-dimensional topology for decades.
  • In a different direction, the PI has for many years been investigating the relationship between two prominent invariants of knots in 3-dimensional space: Khovanov homology and knot Floer homology. These invariants share many formal similarities despite having very different origins, and the PI aims to prove a longstanding conjecture relating them. In a 2015 paper with John Baldwin (Boston College) and Sucharit Sarkar (UCLA), the PI developed a new framework for addressing this conjecture and found some suggestive evidence for why it should hold.
During the grant period, the PI traveled widely to meet with the collaborators mentioned above and participate in seminars and conferences around the world, speaking in eight states, three Canadian provinces, and four countries overseas (UK, Germany, Croatia, and South Korea). These conferences gave him the opportunity to interact with graduate students and other researchers from a wide variety of institutions. In January 2017, the PI gave a seven-hour minicourse on Heegaard Floer homology at a weeklong Winter School in Cambridge, England, with an audience of over fifty graduate students and younger researchers, and he has continued to communicate with other students who have watched the videos of these lectures. The PI also helped to organize conferences at Princeton and in Oaxaca, Mexico, as well as the local topology seminar and departmental colloquium at Princeton. All of these activities have been vital opportunities for the PI to share his research and learn from colleagues, and the PI is grateful to the NSF for its support.
